si1 si1.gif gif 761 34 160 ALTIMG CHNJC 64677 S1872-2067(25)64677-8 10.1016/S1872-2067(25)64677-8 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 XRD patterns for fresh Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ, Ag1-Co1/YSZ catalysts and Ag/YSZ (a) and TEM image (b) and elemental mappings (c–f) for Ag1-Co1/YSZ. A structure model of Ag1-Co1/YSZ is presented in (g). Fig. 2 Semi in situ XPS spectra of Co 2p (a), Ag 3d (b), O 1s (c), and C 1s (d) for representative Co/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ after exposing to H2 at 1073 K for 3 min and mixture gas feed of CH4, CO2 at 1073 K for 10 min. (e) A structure cartoon for the surface structure is diagrammatically illustrated in (d). Fig. 3 Catalytic stability for Ag1-Co1/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Co/YSZ catalysts, displayed for CH4 conversion (a), CO2 conversion (b) and the corresponding H2/CO ratio variations (c) as a function of TOS at 1123 K and pressures from 1.0 to 20.0 bar with a space velocity of 3636 mL h–1 g-cat–1. The dashed line in (a) indicates the equilibrium conversion of CH4. Fig. 4 (a) XRD patterns of spent Ag-Co/YSZ. TEM micrographs (b–f) and nanoparticle dispersion (g) of Co for spent Ag1-Co1/YSZ. Fig. 5 CO2-TGA (a), air-TGA (b), quantity of coke detected on typical samples (c) and Raman pattern (d) for typical spent Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ catalysts. Fig. 6 TPSR plots of Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ, conducted under ambient pressure, CH4= CO2 = 15 mL min–1, T = 323–1173 K. Fig. 7 (a) Activation energy and TOF value of Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ. (b–e) relationship among CH4 turnover rate and gas partial pressure (CH4, CO2, H2, CO). (f) TOF value and E a for Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ Fig. 8 Potential energy profiles along the reaction coordinate for DRM on representative fcc- Co(111) and Ag-Co(111) surfaces. Fig. 9 (a) Gibbs free energy diagrams for DRM over Co (111) through CH+O path, Ag-Co(111) through C+O path at 1123 K. Flux analysis of DRM under experimental reactor inlet conditions (1123 K, 20 bar of total pressure, with a gas composition of 50% CH4, 50% CO2, 0% CO, 0% H2, and 0% H2O) over Ag-Co(111) (b), Co(111) (c). The arrows, which are labeled with the percentage of the total reaction flux, show the direction the reversible elementary steps actually proceed. The percentage of the reaction flux was calculated as the absolute value of the net rate for that elementary step divided by the rate for methane consumption. Fig. 10 (a) The model of graphene island is semi-hexagonal and attached to a step edge. The total energy (E) of a graphene island, the edge and bulk energies on Co (b), and Ag-Co (c) as a function of number of C atoms Ntot. It is economical to perform methane and carbon dioxide reforming (DRM) under industrially relevant high-pressure conditions, but the harsh operation condition poses a grand challenge for coke-resistant catalyst design. Here, we propose to boost the coke- tolerance of Co catalyst by applying a contact potential introduced by immiscible Ag clusters. We demonstrate that Co clusters separated by neighboring Ag on Yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) support can serve as a coke- and sintering-resistant DRM catalyst under diluent gas-free, stoichiometric CH4 and CO2 feeding, 1123 K and 20 bar. Since immiscible metals are ubiquitous and metal contact influences surface work function in general, this new design concept may have general implications for tailoring catalytic properties of metals. Graphical Abstract Co particles contacting to immiscible Ag has been proposed as coke-resistant catalyst to perform methane dry reforming under harsh conditions at 1123 K and 20 bars, for decelerated carbon deposition and inhibition of graphic carbon formation through surface nucleation. Keywords Methane dry reforming Carbon dioxide Heterogeneous catalysis Co Ag 1 Introduction Methane reforming with CO2, known as dry reforming (DRM, CH4 + CO2 = 2CO+ 2H2), provides a promising route to convert the two greenhouse gases into valuable syngas, a mixture of CO and H2, to be used as feedstock for downstream production of olefins, acetic acid, dimethyl ether, high alcohols and hydrogen, etc. [ 1 ]. One major hurdle for the practical deployment of DRM is carbon deposition on catalyst surface under industrially relevant, pressurized operation conditions (10–40 bar) [ 2 ]. Elevated pressure means higher capacity and smaller gas volume, as well as lower investment and operating costs, while also saving compression for downstream use of syngas. Nevertheless, deposition of carbon is thermodynamically and kinetically favored with increase of pressure (Fig. S1), making it particularly daunting to identify a robust catalyst. In addition, the gas phase cracking of CH4 to form C2H2, C3-C4 olefins, C6H6, etc. [ 3 ] can aggravate the situation, since these precursors are more prone to form at elevated temperature and pressure and tend to deposit on metal surfaces. Severe coke deposition can lead to catalyst deactivation, catalyst pellet pulverization or disruption of operation [ 4 ]. CH4 cracking is the only thermodynamically feasible side reaction that leads to carbon formation (Table S1) at high temperature conditions, that is often required to achieve high conversions [ 5 ]. Two carbon deposition pathways have been unveiled thus far. In the surface mediated mechanism, CH4 sequentially dissociates on metal surfaces into CH x (x = 1–3) and surface C* atoms, which further undergoes carbon-carbon coupling and continuous nucleation at under-coordinated sites, to afford encapsulating or whisker carbon (also known as filamentous carbon) [ 4 ]. Alternatively, in dissolution mechanism, C* atoms dissolve into the bulky metal particles and precipitate at the rear side by forming carbon filament [ 6,7 ]. Correspondingly, several catalyst design concepts have been proposed to combat carbon deposition by interrupting whisker carbon formation processes, such as, (1) introducing inert additives that preferentially occupy low-coordination sites (such as sulfur in methane steam reforming, known as the SPARG process [ 8 ], or Au [ 9 ], Sn [ 10 ], etc.); (2) modifying the surface structure of catalysts by alloying to form bimetallic catalysts (such as Rh [ 11 ], Ir [ 12 ], Pt [ 13 ], Fe [ 14 ], etc.) that accelerate oxidation of C*, while preventing carbon dissolution into bulk metals; (3) adding alkali or alkali earth metal promoters, like K2O [ 15 ], BaO [ 16 ] CaO [ 17 ] to increase surface adsorption of CO2; and (4) controlling metal particle size by atomic layer deposition [ 18 ], exsolution from solid solution oxides [ 19 ]. Unfortunately, previous investigations are mostly conducted at ambient pressures, while the stability under more harsh, high pressure conditions remains largely unexplored. Recently, some of us have reported Co1Rh3 clusters as stable DRM catalyst [ 11 ], and Ir-Ni as bi-reforming catalyst [ 12 ] at elevated pressures, but they are complained by industry to be prohibitively expensive for practical use, for the adoption of top expensive metals. It is still desirable to discover inexpensive, durable catalysts to run DRM at high pressures. Finding new ways to control electronic and geometric structures of catalysts is essential to modulate their catalytic properties. In particular, the catalytic properties of a metal catalyst are solely dependent on their electronic structure, as it determines the adsorption mode for reactants, their transformation pathways to various intermediates, and the final products that can be generated, as well as the rates for their formation [ 20 ]. According to the Hammer-Nørskov model [ 21 ], d-band center is a universally applicable descriptor of electronic structure for metals to account for catalytic properties of transition metals, and have well explained surface activities and influencing factors [ 22–24 ]. The electronic structure can so far be manipulated by alloying [ 25,26 ], formation of surface/subsurface alloy [ 9 ], controlling of metal particle size [ 27 ], concentration of under-coordinated sites (such as steps) [ 28 ], and exposing facets [ 29 ], lattice strain [ 30 ], and introduction of promoters [ 31 ] or metal-support interactions [ 32 ]. On the other hand, contact of two distinct metals can build up a contact potential as electrons flow from metal with low work function to the one with high work function, therefore, influencing their electronic structure by forming a common Fermi energy [ 33 ]. Such contact phenomena have long been understood and used commercially in fabrication of thermocouple, electronic component, semiconductor [ 34 ], etc. Nonetheless, the potential of regulating the location of d-band center for a metal catalyst by contacting to a second metal, as a means to influence electronic structure and promote catalytic properties, remains to be unlocked. Here, as a proof of concept, we propose to boost the coke-tolerance of Co catalyst by applying a contact potential introduced by immiscible Ag clusters. We shall demonstrate first that Co particles separated by neighboring Ag on Yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) support can serve as a coke- and sintering- resistant DRM catalyst under harsh conditions of diluent gas-free, stoichiometric CH4 and CO2 feeding, 1123 K and 20 bars. The time-on-stream (TOS) stability has been enhanced and formation of detrimental whisker carbon can be suppressed by the formulated catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the passivation of Co surface by contacting Ag clusters has changed the changed work function, resulting in passivation of the intrinsic activity of Co, while lowering the surface carbon affinity and suppressing surface carbon atom nucleation to form whisker carbon. The rationale has been experimentally validated by kinetic studies, discrimination of deposited carbon types and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) detection of surface structure and measurement of work function. Since immiscible metals are ubiquitous and metal contact influences surface work function in general, this new design concept may have general implications for tailoring catalytic properties of metals. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The support YSZ was synthesized according to a method we reported elsewhere [ 35 ]. Supported catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. In the control, monometallic Co/YSZ sample, the content of Co was kept to be 25 mol% (with respect to the percentage of Co/Co+YSZ). The same molar loading was maintained in preparing other samples, and Ag/Co molar ratios were manipulated to be 9/1, 3/1, 1.5/1, 1/1, 0.25/1 and 0.03/1, labeled as Ag9-Co1/YSZ, Ag3-Co1/YSZ, Ag1.5-Co1/YSZ, Ag1-Co1/YSZ, Ag0.25-Co1/YSZ and Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ, respectively. In a typical synthesis of Ag1-Co1/YSZ catalyst (2.00 g), 0.45 g cobalt acetate (Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co. Ltd 99.99%) and 0.30 g silver nitrate (AgNO3, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co. Ltd, 99.9%) were dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water, stirred for 5 h to afford a homogeneous solution, and the support YSZ (1.41 g) powder was added to the solution while continuously stirred for 5 h. The above mixture was dried by rotary evaporation at 343 K till dryness. The obtained powder sample was dried at 363 K for 12 h in a convection oven. The dried powder sample was reduced in a gas mixture of 10% H2 in Ar with a flow of 30 mL min–1 for 5 h at 873 K, after heating with a rate of 3 K min–1 under nitrogen atmosphere in a tube furnace. Thereafter, the sample was cooled to room temperature in nitrogen atmosphere, labeled as Ag y -Co x /YSZ. Before taking the sample out of tube furnace, a mixture gas of 1 vol% O2 in 99 vol% Ar was passed for 30 min to ensure that the surface was passivated by an oxidized utmost layer, while the main body of the catalyst maintained reduced. Gases were purchased from Shanghai Air Liquid Reagent Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The phase composition of the catalysts was performed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/Max-RC) using Cu K α radiation (operating at 40 kV and 40 mA, λ = 1.54 Å). The measurements were carried out with a step time of 1.2 s and step increment of 0.02° in the 2θ angle ranging from 10° to 80°. Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP, Agilent 725 ICP-OES) was used to determine the composition and content of each element of the catalysts before and after the reaction. The surface morphology of catalysts was observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, GeminiSEM 500), and the distribution of metal elements on catalysts surface was analyzed by Energy Dispersive X-ray surface scanning (EDS-Mapping). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and electron tomography were characterized using the JEOL JEM-F200 FEG TEM instrument at an accelerated voltage of 200 kV. The instrument includes a RIO-16 camera with drift correction and a high tilt mount (EM-21010/21340). A series of TEM images were then collected at 3.0° intervals over an Angle range of –60° to +60°. Tomviz software package was used to process the data. GENFIRE algorithm was used for reconstruction and Tomviz was used for visualization. The specific surface area of the catalyst was determined by N2-physisorption, which was calculated using the standard Bruner-Emmett-Teller (BET) model combined with the N2-adsorption isotherm at a test temperature of 77 K. The sample should be degassed at 623 K, 1 × 10–8 atm for 4 h to remove the impurities adsorbed on the surface. The thermal stability of the catalyst was tested by thermal analysis (TGA-DSC, Perkin Elmer) to determine the relationship between catalyst mass and temperature change, surface area carbon content and carbon deposition type. The TOF of catalyst was calculated by measuring the number of active points after catalyst reduction by H2 chemisorption. The catalysts were pretreated by reduction at 1123 K for 2 h to ensure complete reduction of metals, which was followed by heating under Ar atmosphere at 1123 K for 1 h, to remove surface contaminates, before chemical titration by H2. In H2-chemisorpiton, conducted on Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920, the sample was first heated with a ramp of 10 K min–1 to 1123 K in He (mL min–1), held for 1 h before cooling to ambient temperature. After the temperature stabilized, the carrier gas was switched to H2/Ar (30 mL min–1) and purged for 1 h to saturate the surface, the sample was heated with the same ramp to 574 K, and the signal was recorded 10 points s-1. Similar chemisorption procedures have been used to measure the dispersion of Co, as can be found in [ 36–39 ]. The particle size was estimated assuming a hemispheric shape for supported Co, since Ag did not adsorb H2. The valence states of each element of the catalyst sample were analyzed by XPS (reduced under H2 (20 mL min–1) at 1023 K for 2 h, and further, the reduced samples were contacted with feeding reactants (GHSV = 3030 mL h–1 g-cat–1), in a stoichiometric ratio of CH4: CO2 = 1:1.), and the original data were analyzed by Avantage software. The original data of in situ XPS were analyzed by XPS Peak 4.1 software. For ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) measurement of work function for supported catalysts, an unfiltered He-discharge lamp (21.22 eV) was used within the analyzer chamber. To facilitate the observation of secondary electron cutoffs, the samples were negatively biased to –9.0 V. The Fermi level was calibrated using a UPS spectrum obtained from a clean Au substrate sputtered with Ar ions and was taken as the zero binding energy reference for all UPS and XPS spectra. Raman spectroscopy Coke deposition was characterized by Raman spectroscopy (Thermo Scientific). The Raman spectra were acquired in the range 500–3500 cm–1 using a laser with a wavelength of 514.5 nm. The D band is attributable to the presence of amorphous carbon rich in defects (sp 3 carbon), while the G band is associated with stretching of C=C bond in sp 2 carbon, and the G’ band is correlated to combination of the two phonon vibrations. The intensity ratios between G and D band, defined as I G/I D, represent the degree of graphitization for deposited carbon on Ag y -Co x /YSZ. 2.3 Computational details The DFT calculations in this study were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) code [ 40 ]. The BEEF-vdW functional [ 41 ] was employed to treat the exchange and correlation. The interactions of valence electrons with ion cores were represented using the projector-augmented wave method [ 42 ]. The first Brillouin zone of the slab model was sampled using a Monkhorst-Pack grid [ 43 ]. The energy cutoff was 400 eV in all the calculations. The Methfessel-Paxton scheme was used to determine the partial electron occupancies [ 44 ], with an energy smearing of 0.2 eV. Geometry optimization was done until the forces are less than 0.03 eV Å–1. Transition-state geometries were located by the dimer method [ 45 ], and the transition states were verified by frequency calculations where only one imaginary frequency was present. Slab models were first built based on the face-centered cubic (fcc) transition metal Co with the (111) surfaces modeling the terraces of fcc nanoparticles. The Co(111) surface is represented by a p() rectangular supercell containing three layers of metal atoms with 24 metal atoms in each layer. Then, a silver layer containing 9 Ag atoms was put on the first Co layer to form the Ag-Co(111) surface. The bottom two layers in the slabs were fixed at the bulk structure and all the other atoms in the slabs were allowed to relax. A vacuum space of 18 Å was used to avoid periodic interactions between two neighboring slabs along the z axis. The first Brillouin zone of the slabs was sampled with a 1 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid. In addition, a graphene overlayer was placed on the metal surface to calculate the energy of a carbon atom on the graphene-covered surface (Fig. S2(a)), which is expressed as (1) E graphene = (E surface+graphene overlayer – E surface)/Ncarbon where E graphene represents the potential energy of a carbon atom on the graphene-covered metal surface, N graphene denotes the number of carbon atoms in the cell, E surface represents the potential energy of the clean metal surface, and E surface + graphene overlayer represents the potential energy of metal surface plus graphene overlayer. Moreover, we performed DFT calculations on the structure shown in Fig. S2(b) to estimate the edge energy of a graphene island. The energy of an edge carbon atom relative to Egraphene was calculated as (2) ∆E edge = (E surface+graphene edge – E surface – N graphene edge × E graphene)/E edge where ΔE edge is the potential energy of an edge carbon relative to E graphene, N edge is the number of edge carbon atoms of graphene, N graphene edge is the number of carbon atoms in the cell, and E surface + graphene edge is the potential energy of metal surface and graphene with edge carbon atoms. The energy of an adsorbed carbon on surface was calculated as (3) E carbon = E carbon+surface – E surface where E carbon+surface is the total energy of surface and one adsorbed carbon atom. Whether carbon-free operation is possible depends on the kinetic balance as illustrated in the simplified mechanism shown in Scheme 1 . Adsorbed carbon atoms that do not react to gaseous molecules are dissolved in the crystal and carbon whiskers nucleate from the support interface of the crystal. The microkinetic analysis in this work was carried out using a modified CatMAP code [ 46,47 ]. Under the steady-state approximation, the TOFs for all the elementary steps were obtained by solving a mean-field model with coupled differential equations. The Shomate equation was used to calculate the enthalpy (H 0) and entropy (S 0) of gas-phase species, and the Shomate parameters were obtained from the NIST database [ 48 ]. The enthalpy and entropy of reaction intermediates and transition states were estimated under the harmonic approximations as implemented in the ASE package [ 49 ]. The rate constant (k) for the elementary steps were obtained by using the same method as proposed in our previous work [ 50 ]. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Formation and characterization of immiscible bimetallic catalyst Co-Ag YSZ is optional as DRM catalyst support for two reasons: YSZ is thermally stable under DRM conditions and neither Co nor Ag is dissolvable in YSZ, which guarantees that the composition of Ag-Co can be controlled and is invariable during the catalytic evaluations. Second, YSZ is often used as oxygen anion conductor for high temperature (> 1273 K) fuel cells [ 51–53 ]. YSZ can dissolve and allow the transport of O2–, and such oxygen donor can facilitate oxidative removal of intermediate C* over catalyst surface. A series of Ag y -Co x /YSZ with manipulated Ag/Co ratios (9/1, 3/1, 1.5/1, 1/1, 0.25/1 and 0.03/1) were synthesized by precursor salt impregnation and direct reduction. Calcination was not used prior to reduction, to avoid the formation of metallic Ag and Co3O4 particles that caused phase segregation (Figs. S3, S4, XRD patterns and SEM images for calcined samples). XRD patterns for representative Ag1-Co1/YSZ, Co/YSZ and Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ are displayed in Fig. 1(a) . The lattice parameters for the cubic structured YSZ supports were calculated, which are 5.23, 5.25, 5.29, and 5.30 Å for YSZ, fresh Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ, close to that for spent Co/YSZ(5.29 Å), Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ(5.30 Å) and Ag1-Co1/YSZ(5.35 Å), thus, indicating that the YSZ support is essentially invariable during the course of catalytic assessments. Co/YSZ consists of metallic Co particles and YSZ support, while only diffractions from metallic Co can be detected in Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ, owing to the low loading and high dispersion of Ag. In Ag1-Co1/YSZ, diffraction lines from face-centered cubic (fcc) structured Ag (JCPDS No. 87-0717) and Co (JCPDS No. 15-0806) phases are noticeable, despite of their severe overlap with each other [ 54 ], since the two metals are immiscible and do not dissolve into YSZ support [ 55 ]. Figs. 1(b–f) exhibit the TEM images for Ag1-Co1/YSZ and the elemental mapping in the sample, from which the dispersed, individual Ag and Co particles ranging from 20 to 100 nm on the support can be clearly visualized. Co particle-size-distribution is generated in Fig. S5, based on the panoramic observation and statistics, indicating an averaged particle size centered at ca. 32 nm. The Co particles are large because when Co loading is low and dispersion is high, small Co clusters that are susceptible towards oxidation by the presence of CO2 [ 11,56 ] (particularly at ambient pressure, Fig. S6) can be generated, since Co surface is oxophilic with respect to Ni. Higher loadings of Co was avoided for the resultant low dispersion of Co and insufficient catalytic activity (Fig. S7). Hence, the Co loading was kept to be 10%–15%. The high Co loading in catalyst design guaranteed that the generated Co and Ag particles are in contact to neighboring ones. In contrast, from the TEM micrographs for Co/YSZ, larger particles with a weight averaged size of ca. 113 nm can be deduced, showing that the presence of neighboring Ag particles has assisted the dispersion of Co in the fresh catalyst. In the TEM micrographs for fresh Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ (Fig. S8), Ag clusters can rarely be discerned, owing to its high dispersion on Co surface, as Ag can be adsorbed on Co surface by forming surface alloy [ 55 ]. Herein, surface alloy refers to Ag atoms adsorbed on the surface Co particles [ 57,58 ]. From H2 titration method, the Co dispersions on Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ are determined to be 45, 38 and 35 nm, respectively. We have re-calculated the Co particle size distribution on newly obtained TEM data, and weight averaged particle sizes for Co are estimated to be 39, 34 and 32 nm, respectively, which agree well with that of the chemisorption data. Ag-Co are immiscible and tend to form surface alloy structures, as experimentally observed by several authors [ 59–61 ] and theoretically envisaged by Norskov et al. [ 62 ]. To better disclose the immiscible nature of Ag-Co system, support free Ag-Co bulk alloy was generated and measured by XRD and SEM, as illustrated in Fig. S9. Co particles dispersed in continuous Ag phase were observed, from which XRD diffraction lines from Ag can be well resolved, while these from Co were rather weak for the overlapping, coinciding to previous observations [ 54 ]. A 3D tomography of the same sample was presented in Supplementary video 1, which discloses that the catalyst comprises of a particular support whose surface are covered by metallic particles. Characterizations to the rest samples are manifested in Fig. S10, which are close to that for Ag1-Co1/YSZ. Briefly, these measurements consistently disclose the phase composition for Ag1-Co1/YSZ to be immiscible Co particles separated by Ag particles on support, which is distinct from that of Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ, and a geometric structure model is depicted in Fig. 1(g). Other physicochemical properties of these catalysts, including surface area, active surface area, work function and metal loadings, are tabulated in Table 1 . The valent states for these elements and surface composition for Ag1-Co1/YSZ were determined by semi- in situ XPS collected after reduction (exposing to H2 for 3 min at 1073 K) and exposing to reaction atmosphere (CH4= CO2= 15 mL min–1 for 10 min at 1073 K), i.e., transferred inside protection chamber without exposing to ambient conditions, as shown in Figs. 2(a,b) . The Co 2p spectra for Co/YSZ samples after contacting to H2 and reaction atmosphere comprise mainly of Co0 (777.7 and 778.0 eV, 7.0 and 9.8 at%, respectively), in addition to a minor amount of Co2+ (780.2 and 781.1 eV, 6.8 at% and 8.7 at%, respectively), indicating that reduced metallic particles are the active phase, which is also the case for the bimetallic samples. The reduced, fresh Ag1-Co1/YSZ (upon contacting to H2) consists of more Co0(7.1 at%) with respect to Co/YSZ(5.5 at%), suggesting that the contacting to Ag clusters has assisted the reduction of Co. Upon exposing to the reaction atmosphere (CH4 + CO2), the contents of Co in Ag1-Co1/YSZ and Co/YSZ have dropped to 6.2 at% and 4.3 at%, respectively, because the surface oxidation by the presence of CO2, Ag+ signal stems mostly from close to surface region Ag oxidized by O* or dissolved O* in bulk Ag clusters [ 61,62 ], as XPS is a surface sensitive technique. In the Ag 3d spectrum of H2 reduced Ag1-Co1/YSZ, only metallic Ag0 (368.0 eV, 6.3 at%) can be distinguished, and slightly Ag+ (367.8 eV, 0.2 at%) can be observed upon exposing to the reaction atmosphere, owing to surface oxidation by CO2 [ 61 ]. In the corresponding O 1s spectra, both O2– from C–O (286.0 eV) and M-O2– (530.1 eV) can be detected, recommending partial oxidation of metal surfaces, which is in line with observations of Ag+ and Co2+ species. From literature survey, it is infeasible to distinguish Ag0 from Ag+ from the marginal shifts in their binding energies (368.0–368.3 eV) alone, hence, their differentiation requires the reference to the Auger electrons, which is more sensitive to oxidation states of Ag [ 63,64 ]. Two main AES transitions from Ag M4N4,5N4,5 and Ag M5N4,5N4,5 are used to specify the chemical states. The Auger parameter, defined as the difference between Ag 3d 5/2 and Ag M4N4,5N4,5 lines, (4) α = KEAuger + BEPE whereby KEAuger = 1486.71 – Auger (M4N4,5N4,5) represents the Auger kinetic energy for Ag M4N4,5N4,5 spectral line, while BEPE is the binding energy of Ag 3d 5/2 for photoelectrons. The measured KEAuger values are 1134.7, 1135.2, 1136.8, and 1138.8 eV, Fig. S11, and the BEPE are determined to be 368.2, 367.8 368.0, and 367.8 eV, for Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ(H2), Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ(CH2+CO2) and Ag1-Co1/YSZ(H2), Ag1-Co1/ YSZ(CH2+CO2), respectively. Correspondingly, the characteristic α values are calculated to be 726.0 eV(Ag0) and 723.5 eV(Ag+), and 725.5 eV(Ag0) and 722.7 eV(Ag+), for Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ (H2) and Ag1-Co1/YSZ (H2), respectively, and the values are determined to be 725.1 and 722.2, 724.1 and 720.5 eV, over Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ (CH4+CO2) Ag1-Co1/YSZ (CH2+CO2), manifesting the co-existence of both Ag0 and Ag+ in these samples. The determined coexistence of two α values [ 65 ] implies that these sample contain two species [ 66 ]. Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ have close Ag0/Co0 ratio of ca. 1 (Table 2 ), suggesting formation of surface alloy structure, since XPS is a surface sensitive technique. The C 1s spectra for all samples appear to be essentially the same, containing C–C, C–O and C=O species, owing to the low exposure. The surface compositions were also measured by XPS, as compiled in Table 2. The Ag/Co ratios are determined to be 0.36 and 1.26, for Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ samples, respectively. The high Ag content determined by surface-sensitive XPS technique in Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ manifests that Ag resides on top of Co, as can be anticipated by the formation of surface alloy [ 67 ]. On Ag1-Co1/YSZ surface, alike migration of Ag atoms to Co surface can also take place, but signals from neighboring bulk Ag particles may overshadow such contributions. A surface structure model is sketched based on the XPS measurements in Fig. 2(c). The XPS data demonstrate that Ag and Co have been reduced in H2 atmosphere, and the metallic states are preserved upon contacting to the reaction mixture. 3.2 Catalytic stability and coke-tolerance properties under elevated pressures Catalytic assessments of stability were conducted at 1123 K and 1–20 bar, after loading of 1.00 g catalyst diluted with 2.00 g carborundum, with a feeding of 30 mL min–1 CH4, 30 mL min–1 CO2 and 0.6 mL min–1 H2, corresponding to a GHSV of 3636 mL g-cat–1 h–1. H2 was co-fed to advert surface oxidation of Co upon contacting to CO2. The pressure was increased with a step of 5 bar, after maintaining for 12 h, to avoid impacts from surface restructure in pressure manipulations. CH4 and CO2 conversions, and H2/CO ratio variations with TOS are depicted in Fig. 3 . The undoped Co/YSZ catalyst shows high CH4 conversion (94.1%) under ambient pressure, which increases with incremental pressure owing to the kinetic effect, since DRM is a first order reaction of p CH4 (vide infra). When the pressure reached 20 bar, the initial CH4 conversion was 56.6%, and maintained stable for 30 h before falling to 46.2% in 60 h, when the reactor was blocked by severe carbon deposition and the test was stopped. A higher CO2 conversion was always observed, as a consequence of the impact from reverse-water-gas-shift (RWGS), which is often saturated due to the rapid reaction rate, as it consumes H2 and CO2 to generate H2O and CO (Fig. 3(b)) [ 36,68 ]. For the same reason, a lower than 1 ratio of H2/CO was detected (Fig. 3(c)). As RWGS occurs with a faster rate than DRM, virtually on all metal surfaces [ 69 ], such ratio variations are independent of catalyst used, but decided by thermodynamic equilibrium, i.e., on operation conditions. The surface alloy structured Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ catalyst exhibited lowered activity with CH4 conversion of 77.8% at ambient pressure, as also reported in previous reports, owing to the passivating effect of Ag by blocking the highly reactive, low-coordinated sites, and passivating of neighboring Co surface. With the increase of operation pressure to 20 bar, the initial conversion drops to 55.0%, due to a lowered equilibrium conversion. The activity declines continuously during the TOS tests, and eventually arrives at 42.3% after 100 h. Compared with previous reports on Ag promoted Ni catalysts that possess alike surface alloy structure and are rather stable for normal pressure DRM tests [ 70–72 ], one may conclude that surface alloy structured Ag-Co [ 72 ] catalyst is merely stable at low pressure, while is insufficient to run under harsh conditions at elevated pressures. For Ag1-Co1/YSZ, the lowest initial CH4 conversion of 63.3% was perceived at 1 bar, indicating that the presence of neighboring Ag clusters further passivated Co surface with respect to the surface alloy type, control Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ catalyst. The conversion increased to 60.8% at 5 bar, due to kinetic effect of CH4 pressure increase, but dropped at elevated pressures under the influence of thermodynamics. A conversion of 47.2% was measured at 20 bar, which slightly decreases over time in the first 48 h, before levering off thereafter, ending up with a conversion of 41.4% after 100 h. The drop of conversion can originate from sintering of Co particles, as increase of Co particle size (vide infra). Catalytic evaluations of catalysts with varied Ag/Co ratios are reported in Fig. S12, and initial catalytic activity decreases with Ag loading. Compared with the performances of control samples, it is concluded that Ag1-Co1/YSZ shows passivated activity, but improved long term stability. As have been pointed by previous reports, formation of deposited carbon may not necessarily lead to catalyst deactivation, as surface diffusion of whisker carbon moves metal particles to atop of filaments. Therefore, crosscheck of residue carbon over spent catalysts is required to verify the coke-resistant property of DRM catalysts. 3.3 Characterizations of spent catalysts and residue carbon The spent catalysts were first subjected to characterizations by XRD, as outlined in Fig. 4(a) . Diffractions out of metallic fcc phase Ag and Co, in addition to these from the YSZ support, can be observed from spent Ag1-Co1/YSZ catalysts. On the control samples, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Co/YSZ, besides diffraction lines from metallic Co phase and support, an obvious graphitic carbon (26.60°) diffraction line can be noticed, showing that carbon adsorbed on their surfaces have nucleated and grown into graphitic carbon. By comparison, over Ag1-Co1/YSZ surface, surface carbon nucleation has been inhibited, highlighting the critical role for the presence of neighboring Ag clusters for enhancement of catalyst stability at high pressures. TEM and FE-SEM micrographs and elemental mappings for spent Ag1-Co1/YSZ are displayed in Figs. 4(b,c) and Fig. S13, respectively. To determine the particle size, extra TEM measurements for the spent catalysts were performed, as now included in Fig. S8. It is seen that the Co particle sizes are 39, 34, and 32 nm, for fresh Co/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ, and Ag1-Co1/YSZ, respectively, while on the spent catalysts, the Co particle sizes have increased to 109, 87, and 61 nm. Hence, by comparison, one may conclude that the presence of Ag has hindered coalescence of Co particles. The Co particle sizes in fresh Co/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ are deduced using Scherrer formula to be 27 and 24 nm, respectively for fresh samples, which are different from TEM data, likely due to impact of neighboring Ag the induced strain [ 73 ]. For the spent catalysts, Co particle sizes in Co/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ are estimated to be 124 and 66 nm, based on Scherrer equation. It also corroborates the structural integrity of the catalyst during the TOS tests. It is speculated that Ag particles repel adjacent Co particles for the immiscible system, which may have hindered their coalescence, hence, forming a sintering resistant catalyst. On the same catalyst, no whisker carbon was observed, which is strikingly different from that of spent Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Co/YSZ (as indicated by a red arrow in Fig. S14), from which plenty of whisker carbon can be visualized. The amount of deposited carbon was determined by consecutive TGA measurements under CO2 and air atmosphere, in order to quantify the amount of CO2 oxidizable carbonaceous species and recalcitrant residue carbon that can only be gasified by O2. The CO2-TGA curves for Ag1-Co1/YSZ disclose two weight losses at 526 and 993 K, amounting to a total value of 3.62 wt%, while only negligible 0.02 wt% weight loss is measured in air-TGA. In contrast, weight losses of 12.85 wt% and 55.32 wt% were determined in CO2-TGA, 0.88 wt% and 3.33 wt% were determined in air-TGA, respectively, over Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Co/YSZ. These data are diagrammatically expressed in histogram in Figs. 5(a–c) . In the corresponding Raman spectra, Fig. 5(d)., G (1581.4 cm–1) and G’ bands (1576.8 cm–1) arising from C=C bond in sp 2 carbon and combination of the two phonon vibrations, can be regarded as evidence for the presence of graphitic carbon, while the D band (1348.3 cm–1) stemming from sp 3 carbon rich in defect, which is often attributed to amorphous carbon [ 75,76 ]. The integral peak intensity ratio, IG /ID , as index of graphitization, are calculated to rank in the order of Ag1-Co1/YSZ (0.54) < Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ (0.64) < Co/YSZ (1.35), showing far less graphitization of carbon for the former. Collectively, carbon residue measurements corroborated that the amount of carbon is the least and essentially only CO2 oxidizable, less graphitized carbon can be formed on Ag1-Co1/YSZ. 3.4 Kinetic effect of immiscible bimetallic catalyst Co-Ag Kinetic influences are important for TOS stability because net carbon accumulation is a dynamic process, which only occurs when surface carbon deposition overrates its gasification. The kinetic effects of Ag1-Co1/YSZ, the control, surface alloy structured Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and undoped Co/YSZ, were also disclosed by temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) spectroscopy and kinetic studies. The TPSR was conducted using a feeding gas mixture of 15 mL min–1 CH4 and 15 mL min–1 CO2, with a ramp of 5 K min–1. Fig. 6 shows the effluent composition variations as a function of temperature for the three catalysts monitored by mass spectroscopy. For pristine Co/YSZ, the onset temperature is 698 K for the conversion of CH4 and CO2, with concurrent detection of CO, H2 and H2O, as products. Close to full conversion of reactants are observed at 1112 K. The onset temperatures on Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and Ag1-Co1/YSZ catalysts have been increased to 788 and 882 K, respectively. The high temperature shifts can be ascribed to the passivation of Co surface by Ag, which is more prominent for Ag1-Co1/YSZ than that of Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ. Kinetic studies were conducted under differential reactor model conditions with low CH4 conversions (below 10%), using a total feeding flow of 60.0 cm3 min–1, at ambient pressure (0.1 MPa). The impacts from heat transfer and diffusion were ruled out to ensure correct data collection, as described in our previous report [ 77 ]. The CH4 partial pressures were manipulated to be 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 kPa, while that of CO2 were varied to be 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 kPa, and the H2 and CO were varied between 0 and 45 kPa, N2 as the balance gas. The reaction rate, expressed as elimination of CH4 because CO2 can also be consumed by RWGS reaction. Over the three catalysts, the reaction rates are found to increase with p CH4, but are independent of P CO2, P CO, P H2. By assuming methane dissociation to be the rate determining step (RDS) and surface coverage by reactants and products to be negligibly small, the reaction rate can be depicted the equation (Eq. (4)) [ 78 ] (5) r M = k M × p CH4 where r M represents for the reaction rate, k represents for reaction rate constant, M = Co, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ or Ag1-Co1, indicating the tested catalysts, p CH4 is partial pressure of methane. The first order rate to p CH4, indicates that methane activation is kinetic important step, while the zeroth order rate to CO2 and products means that their surface coverages are low. In previous reports [ 11,74 ], a small, negative deviation from zeroth order for CO2 were reported when Co loadings were low (3 wt%–10 wt%), which likely generated smaller Co particles that were more oxophilic than herein used, hence, increasing the coverage of surface O*derived from CO2 dissociation to a measurable extent. The activation energies were deduced from Arrhenius plots recorded from 1073 to 993 K, which were determined to be 174.3 ± 8.1, 169.1 ± 4.7 and 123.9 ± 5.5 kJ mol–1, for Ag1-Co1/YSZ, Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ and undoped Co/YSZ, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 7(a) . The measured activation energy reflects the barrier for CH4 dissociation, as the RDS step for both DRM and coke deposition [ 79 ]. Similar influences of Ag on Ni surface have been used by some of us [ 71 ] and others [ 54 ] to circumvent coke deposition for ambient pressure operation of DRM, which can be explained by a combined geometric and electronic effect [ 70 ]. An activation energy of 174.3 kJ mol–1 is inferred on Ag1-Co1/YSZ, meaning a strong passivating of Co surface activity by the contacting Ag particles compared to surface alloy type catalyst, which originates from an electronic effect. This passivating effect not only influence the kinetics of the main DRM reaction, but also brings the benefit of slowed coke deposition rate. In-depth explanation for the promoting role of Ag entails DFT calculations (vide infra). The turnover frequency (TOF) was also determined under the following reaction conditions: 1073 K, 1 bar, CH4:CO2:H2:N2 = 20:20:1:60, GHSV = 60600 mL h–1 g-cat–1, as juxtaposed together with activation energies in Fig. 7(f). The measured TOFs, normalized to active site numbers from chemical titrations by H2 (Table 1), descend with an order of Co/YSZ (1.61 ± 0.04 s–1) > Ag0.03-Co1/YSZ (1.33 ± 0.11 s–1) > Ag1-Co1/YSZ (0.94 ± 0.07 s–1), agreeing well with the variations for activation energies. As TOF values reflect the per site activity, the intrinsic activity variations can only root in an electronic effect, since geometric blockage of active sites would not impact measured TOF. 3.5 DFT calculations of reaction mechanism, microkinetic analysis and modelling of carbon nucleation To shed light on the impact of contacting Ag on DRM reaction mechanism over Co surface, a catalyst model on the most stable fcc Co(111) surface with clustered Ag has been established, as shown in Fig. S15. For comparison, the reaction was also investigated over undoped Co(111) facet. The DRM reaction on representative Co sites sitting 3 atoms away from Ag cluster were calculated. The work function on Co was calculated to be 4.90 eV, while on Ag-Co(111) was 4.65 eV, close to the experimentally measured data. A total of 22 involved elementary reactions were considered in the reaction network, as tabulated in Table S2. DRM proceeds through CH4 dissociation to CH3*, CH2*, CH* and surface C*(Cα), co-producing H*. CH* and C* can be oxidized to derive CHO* or CO* by coupling to O*, which eventually desorb as CO. Co-reactant CO2 is dissociated into CO* and O* that serve as oxidant to interact with surface C*. Fig. 8 shows that CH4 dissociation and the coupling of C* or CH* with O*/OH* is likely to be kinetically relevant. Meanwhile, coupling of H* and O* generates H2O in the side RWGS reaction. The C*-C* coupling and graphitic carbon formation was not regarded at this stage. The corresponding optimized geometries for adsorbed reactants, transition states, and products are shown in Figs. S16–S19, respectively, on the Ag-Co(111) and Co(111) surfaces. On the Co(111) and Ag-Co(111) surfaces, CH4 dissociates at the Atop site and the dissociated H* is oriented towards the neighboring bridge sites. Moreover, the activation energy for the first dehydrogenation of CH4 on the Ag-Co(111) surface is larger than that on the Co(111) surface, indicating that CH4 is prone to break the C-H bond on the Co(111) surface. Then, the dehydrogenation processes of CH3*, CH2*, and CH* all occur at the threefold hollow site, with the dissociated H* tilted towards the neighboring Atop site. The Gibbs free energy diagrams on the two surfaces are shown in Fig. 9(a) , from which the CH4 sequential dissociation and surface C* or CH* oxidative coupling to O*/OH* are identified to be kinetically important. The energetic barriers for CH4 dissociation are found to be 116.7 and 122.5 kJ mol–1 over Co(111) and Ag-Co(111) surfaces, respectively. The kinetic barriers for C* and CH* coupling to O* are determined to be 146.7 and 119.6 kJ mol–1 over Co(111), which have been increased to 128.3 and 145.7 kJ mol–1 on Ag-Co(111). The degree of rate control was applied to identify the rate-determining step, revealing that the activation of C-H bonds in methane is the rate-determining step on both the Co(111) and Ag-Co(111) surfaces, which is consistent with the reaction orders obtained from the kinetic experiments. Since both C*-O* and CH*-O* coupling can constitute the overall DRM, their individual contributions has been measured using flux analysis, as demonstrated in Figs. 9(b,c). The analysis results indicate that on Co(111) the CH* interacts primarily with O* whereas on Ag-Co(111) CH* would continue to dehydrogenate to form C*, which in turn to reacts with O* to form CO*. The contributions of the reactions C* + O* and CH* + O* to the dominant pathways are shown in Figs. S20(a,b) as a function of reaction temperature. The variation of the dominant reaction pathways also changes the identity of the most abundant surface intermediates (MARI) and their surface coverages, as presented in Figs. S20(c,d), which indicates that the surface of both catalysts are mainly covered by O*, regardless of the operation temperatures. As can be seen in Figs. S20(c,d), the coverage of O* slightly decreases from around 0.63 to 0.60 ML when the temperature rises from 973 to 1123 K, whereas the change in the MARI on the Co(111) surface was not significant. The influence of pressure on the dominant reaction pathway is shown in Figs. S21(a,b), suggesting that the pressure plays a minor role in determining the dominant pathway, despite of the increase in TOFs. Meanwhile, the MARI does not change with pressure, as demonstrated in Figs. S21(c,d). The nature and surface coverage of MARI are found to be less affected by pressure and temperature variations, likely because Co is more oxophilic than that of Ni, with binding energies to C* of –6.4 and –6.2 eV, and binding energies to O* of –5.5 and –5.2 eV [ 80,81 ], respectively. To explain the synergistic effect between Ag and Co, the density of states (DOS) projected onto the d-states of surface metal atoms on Ag-Co(111) surface was calculated and compared with that on Co(111), as shown in Fig. S22. From Co(111) to Ag-Co(111), it can be seen that the d-band center of Co is shifted downward by 1.73 eV, which agrees well with the activation barriers derived from the kinetic studies. The TOFs under the conditions of our experimental studies were estimated to be 9.89 and 7.97 s–1, respectively, on Co and Ag-Co, and agree qualitatively with the data obtained experimentally (Table 1). Furthermore, the activation energies are derived to be 127.9 and 136.0 kJ mol–1 on Co(111) and Ag-Co(111) under the experimental conditions (Fig. S23), which are also consistent to the measured data. In short, the DFT calculations revealed that presence of Ag clusters changes the reaction pathway from CH* into C* oxidative coupling, and the surface of Ag-Co(111) is mainly covered by O*, instead of C*, under pressurized operation conditions. Hence, surface carbon accumulation can be mitigated. In the TOS test, the accumulation of adsorbed C* atoms on the surface may enhance their nucleation and formation of undesirable graphene layers (encapsulating carbon) or whisker carbon. Hence, nucleation is considered to be the key step for transformation of intermediate, CO2 oxidizable carbonaceous species to recalcitrant carbon. To study the influence of Ag cluster on carbon nucleation, the critical nucleus size was calculated on Co(111) and Ag-Co(111), following a method proposed by Nørskov et al. [ 80 ], as shown in Fig. 10 . The critical size of graphene on Co(111) is found to be 21 atoms, which is far smaller than that on Ag-Co(111) (648 carbon atoms), corresponding to the ensemble size of 0.84 and 4.69 nm of a semi-circular carbon island, which explains why merely soft carbon was observed on the spent Ag1-Co1/YSZ catalyst. The coke resistance of the Ag-Co(111) surface can therefore be rationalized surface coverage by MARI O*, i.e., lowered C* coverage, and suppress carbon nucleation that inhibits the formation of recalcitrant, encapsulating or whisker carbon. Such a promoting role can be attributed to combined electronic and geometrical effects, which is more influential by contacting to Ag clusters than by the adsorbed Ag atoms on the surface alloy structured catalyst. 3.6 General discussion Taken into account DRM reaction mechanism, kinetic features and whisker carbon formation process, the influences of neighboring Ag clusters on coke-resistant properties have been speculated, and the simplified mechanism is sketch in Scheme 1. In DRM, CH4 dissociation into surface CH* or C* atoms, with CH* surface coupling being the dominant gasification route on Co surface, while C* coupling to O* still being the main route over Ag-Co surface. The DFT calculated reaction rate for CH4 dissociation rate has been markedly slowed, due to the increase of energy barrier exerted by neighboring Ag clusters, which also suggests a slowed rate for surface carbon deposition. Meanwhile, microkinetic simulations for surface coverage variations with operation conditions, i.e., temperature and pressure, reveal that the MARI being almost invariant O*, instead of C*. Carbon formation can be avoided when the concentration of surface carbon is small, in other words, when the steady state activity of carbon is smaller than that is required for nucleation to take place. The steady state activity is proportional with [C*] which can be expressed as [ 81 ]: (6) a c ≈ [ C * ] ≈ k 1 k 2 k 3 k 4 1 [ O * ] 2 whereby k 1 is the rate constant for the activation of methane, k 2 is the rate constant for the dissociation of CH* to C*(Cα*), k 3 is the rate constant of CH* coupling with O* to produce CO and k4 is the rate constant of C*(Cα*) coupling with O* to produce CO. Surface coverage increase implies two things: an accelerated surface C* oxidation and less C* accumulation, which kinetically disfavor nucleation of surface carbon atoms that often requires a high coverage. Both the slowed carbon deposition and accelerated carbon gasification suggest that a dynamic stability can be maintained over Ag-Co surface. Furthermore, modeling of surface carbon atom surface nucleation and calculation of the critical size of carbon island necessary to form stable nuclei manifest that the critical size has been remarkably enlarged, such that virtually no stable nuclei can be generated on Ag-Co. It follows that only CO2 oxidizable carbonaceous species, which can be regarded as intermediate in the reaction network of DRM, can be formed, whereas the transformation of these surface carbonaceous species into graphitic carbon, like recalcitrant encapsulating or whisker carbon, has been inhibited. Both impacts can be correlated to the change of electronic structure for Ag-Co, with a notable passivating of surface with respect to surface alloy type catalyst. Hence, contacting Ag clusters are not spectators, but a modifier to the electronic structure of Co surface. 4 Conclusions We proposed the use of Ag1-Co1 immiscible particles as a robust DRM catalyst under harsh, pressurized operation conditions. The catalyst showed passivated activity, boosted long term stability and lowered amount of deposited carbon, on which only CO2 oxidizable, intermediate carbonaceous species can be formed. The coke-resistant properties are associated to the slowed carbon deposition rate, suppressed surface carbon nucleation to afford graphitic carbon, as well as the formation of O* as the MARI under high pressure conditions, according to DFT calculations. The experimentally observed change of work function derived from UPS method, increase of activation barrier for methane dissociation and absence of encapsulating or whisker carbon, agree well with DFT anticipated properties and destabilizing of carbon island necessary for nucleation on Ag1-Co1 catalyst. Despite that metal-support interaction has been frequently used to influence catalytic properties of metals, the manipulation of catalytic performance by neighboring metal particles has barely been investigated, which can be more influential than that of the support for the conductor nature of metallic particles. Therefore, the influences catalytic behavior for metal surfaces by contacting to a second metal pave a new way to modulate electronic structure of metal catalysts and deserve in-depth future explorations. coredata.dc:description: It is economical to perform methane and carbon dioxide reforming (DRM) under industrially relevant high-pressure conditions, but the harsh operation condition poses a grand challenge for coke-resistant catalyst design. Here, we propose to boost the coke- tolerance of Co catalyst by applying a contact potential introduced by immiscible Ag clusters. We demonstrate that Co clusters separated by neighboring Ag on Yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) support can serve as a coke- and sintering-resistant DRM catalyst under diluent gas-free, stoichiometric CH4 and CO2 feeding, 1123 K and 20 bar. Since immiscible metals are ubiquitous and metal contact influences surface work function in general, this new design concept may have general implications for tailoring catalytic properties of metals.

coredata.dc:title: Co particles separated by immiscible Ag on yttria-stabilized zirconia as durable methane dry reforming catalyst under pressurized conditions
